articles.summary: Hummingbirds in California are rapidly evolving. Their beaks are getting pointier and pokier. Scientists believe the rapid change has been driven by humans, whose supplemental feeders and introduced plant species have helped change the way these hummingbirds eat.

articles.title: ASA Savings and Loans collaborates with Bibiani Sectech to plant over 500 trees
articles.author: FT Online
articles.summary: ASA partners with schools to plant trees in support of Ghana's Green Agenda. The team from the Bibiani Business Center of the company joined the students and staff to plant the trees. Climate change has led to drastic changes in weather patterns, rising sea levels, and biodiversity destruction.

articles.title: Different phases of evolution during ice age
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Cold-adapted animals started to evolve 2.6 million years ago when the permanent ice at the poles became more prevalent. There is still no evidence that cold- adapted animals exist today.    for the time being, however, there are no living examples of them.

articles.title: Hundreds of Australia's rarest species face extinction without urgent habitat protection: study
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: 220 of Australia's most critically endangered species are at risk of extinction due to fragmented habitats and inadequate protections, according to a new study by Griffith University. Globally, species with small distributions face disproportionate extinction risk. Land use change is more likely to have catastrophic consequences.

articles.title: 3 Questions Inland Regions Must Ask As Hurricane Season Approaches
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene is a reminder that inland regions are vulnerable too. Here are three questions non-coastal communities should ask themselves as hurricane season approaches and what they can do to prepare for it.       .   "What do you need to know?"

articles.title: Climate expert: We're talking about global warming ‘in the wrong way'
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: Society is talking about climate change in the wrong way, scientist says. Friederike Otto leads work on attributing the role of climate change to devastating heatwaves, floods and storms. She says extreme weather is the way that people experienced rising temperatures.

articles.title: Climate impacts in India: Experience, worry, and attribution to global warming
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: As the climate warms, extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and severe across India. Indians have recently experienced extreme heat waves, floods, water shortages, and irregular monsoon patterns. These events harm lives and livelihoods and shape how people perceive both climate change and the environment.

articles.title: States and cities fear a disaster season full of unknowns amid federal cuts
articles.author: Sun Sentinel
articles.summary: States and cities along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts are bracing for the hurricane season. There's no plan in writing for how FEMA intends to respond during this disaster season, so they don't know how significant cuts at vital federal agencies will affect weather forecasts and emergency response.

articles.title: Is Africa splitting in two? Scientists uncover fiery force tearing the continent apart faster than predict
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: East Africa is splitting faster than previously thought due to a fiery upwelling of sea water, according to a new study.   Â      in East Africa is breaking apart faster than before. The study was published in the journal "Science and Society".

articles.title: Earthquake of 5.5 magnitude jolts New Australia's South Wales, says GFZ
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Magnitude 5.5 earthquake struck New South Wales in Australia on Saturday. The quake was at a depth of 10 km (6.21 miles), GFZ said. The German Research Center for Geosciences (GFZ) confirmed the quake.

articles.title: 2024 sees record warm temperatures, less sea ice cover in Gulf of St. Lawrence
articles.author: Moosejaw Today
articles.summary: Last year, the Gulf of St. Lawrence recorded its highest maximum surface temperature and lowest seasonal volume of ice cover in decades. Surface temperatures and ice cover are directly related to air temperature. Last year's air temperature was the warmest, which gave the sea surface temperature.

articles.title: Forecasters predict busiest hurricane season in years amid NOAA and FEMA cuts
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: The official hurricane season is days away. Forecasters predict it could be one of the busiest in years. The prediction comes as NOAA and FEMA are going through major cuts under President Trump's overhaul. Karen Hua reports.    for CNN iReport.com.

articles.title: Gaseous! Bloomberg News Hails ‘Penguin Poop' as Savior of Antarctica from Global Warming
articles.author: Joseph Vazquez
articles.summary: Bloomberg News published a story about penguin feces as a way to prevent Antarctica melting due to global warming. The Washington Post and JunkScience founder Steve Milloy are critical of the story and the fact that Antarctica is warming and gaining ice, as the New York Post reports.
